# Utsuro-bune

*Revision ID: 1155831638 | Timestamp: 2023-05-19T23:07:02Z*

---

[[Fief-of-Lord-Ogasawara.png|thumb|300px|Utsuro-bune. Manjudō, the strange boat drifted ashore on fief of Lord Ogasawara.](File:Utsuro-Bune-Manjudō-Drifted-Ashore-on)]

, also **Utsuro-fune,** and **Urobune**, was an unknown object that allegedly washed ashore in 1803 in [province](Hitachi)(Hitachi province) on the eastern coast of [Japan](Japan). When defining Utsuro-bune, the bune part means "boat" while Utsuro means empty, or hollow. Accounts of the tale appear in four texts: *Oushuku Zakki* (1815), *Toen shōsetsu* (1825), *Hyōryū kishū* (1835) and *Ume-no-chiri* (1844).

According to [legend](legend), a young woman aged 18–20 years old, arrived on a local beach aboard the "hollow ship" on February 22, 1803. Fishermen brought her inland to investigate further, but the woman was unable to communicate in [Japanese](Japanese language). She was very different from anyone else there. The fishermen then returned her and her vessel to the sea, where it drifted away.

[Historian](Historian)s, [ethnologists](ethnology) and [physicist](physicist)s such as [Tanaka](Kazuo)(Kazuo Tanaka) and [Kunio](Yanagita)(Yanagita Kunio) have evaluated the "legend of the hollow boat" as part of a long-standing tradition within Japanese [folklore](folklore).Kunio Yanagita, Fanny Hagin Mayer, Nihon Hōsō Kyōkai: *The Yanagita Kunio guide to the Japanese folk tale*. Indiana University Press, Bloomington (IN) 1986, , p. 176–178. Alternatively, certain [ufologists](Ufology) have claimed that the story represents evidence for a [encounter](close)(close encounter) with extraterrestrial life.

The term "Utsuro-bune" in Japanese consists of two parts: "Utsuro," which means empty or hollow, and "bune," which means boat. Together, "Utsuro-bune" refers to a mysterious object described as an "unknown object" or a "hollow boat" that reportedly washed ashore in 1803 in Japan.

**Delhi**;  *dillī*;  *dillī*;  *dêhlī*, informally  *dillī*),

*

*

*}}, officially the **National Capital Territory** (**NCT**) **of Delhi**, is a city and a [territory](union)(union territory) of [India](India) containing [Delhi](New)(New Delhi), the capital of India. Straddling the [Yamuna](Yamuna) river, primarily its western or right bank, Delhi shares borders with the state of [Pradesh](Uttar)(Uttar Pradesh) in the east and with the state of [Haryana](Haryana) in the remaining directions. The NCT covers an area of . According to the 2011 census, Delhi's city proper population was over 11 million, while the NCT's population was about 16.8 million. Delhi's urban agglomeration, which includes the satellite cities [Ghaziabad](Ghaziabad), [Faridabad](Faridabad), [Gurgaon](Gurgaon) and [Noida](Noida) in an area known as the [Capital Region](National)(National Capital Region (India)) (NCR), has an estimated population of over 28 million, making it the [metropolitan area in India](largest)(List of metropolitan areas in India) and the [in the world](second-largest)(List of urban areas by population) (after [Tokyo](Tokyo)).

The topography of the medieval fort [Qila](Purana)(Purana Qila) on the banks of the river Yamuna matches the literary description of the citadel [Indraprastha](Indraprastha) in the Sanskrit epic *[Mahabharata](Mahabharata)*; however, excavations in the area have revealed no signs of an ancient built environment. From the early 13th century until the mid-19th century, Delhi was the capital of two major empires, the [sultanate](Delhi)(Delhi sultanate) and the [Empire](Mughal)(Mughal Empire), which covered large parts of [Asia](South)(South Asia). All three [World Heritage Site](UNESCO)(UNESCO World Heritage Site)s in the city, the [Minar](Qutub)(Qutub Minar), [Tomb](Humayun's)(Humayun's Tomb), and the [Fort](Red)(Red Fort), belong to this period. Delhi was the early centre of [Sufism](Sufism) and [Qawwali](Qawwali) music.  The names of [Auliya](Nizamuddin)(Nizamuddin Auliya) and [Khusrau](Amir)(Amir Khusrau) are prominently associated with it. The [Khariboli](Khariboli) dialect of Delhi was part of a linguistic development that gave rise to the literature of [Urdu](Urdu) and [Standard Hindi](Modern)(Modern Standard Hindi). Major Urdu poets from Delhi include [Taqi Mir](Mir)(Mir Taqi Mir) and [Ghalib](Mirza)(Mirza Ghalib). Delhi was a major centre of the [Rebellion of 1857](Indian)(Indian Rebellion of 1857). In 1911, [Delhi](New)(New Delhi), a southern region within Delhi, became the capital of the [Indian Empire](British)(British Indian Empire).  During the [of India](Partition)(Partition of India) in 1947, Delhi was transformed from a Mughal city to a Punjabi one, losing two-thirds of its Muslim residents, in part due to the pressure brought to bear by arriving Hindu and Sikh refugees from western Punjab.

*

*  After independence in 1947, New Delhi continued as the capital of the [of India](Dominion)(Dominion of India), and after 1950 of the [of India](Republic)(Republic of India).

Delhi ranks [among the Indian states and union territories](fifth)(List of Indian states and territories by Human Development Index) in [development index](human)(human development index). Delhi has the [second-highest](List of Indian states and union territories by GDP per capita) [per capita](GDP)(Gross domestic product) in India (after [Goa](Goa)). Although a [territory](union)(union territory), the political administration of the NCT of Delhi today more closely resembles that of a [state](States of India) of India, with its own legislature, high court and an executive council of ministers headed by a [Minister](Chief)(Chief Minister of Delhi). New Delhi is jointly administered by the federal [of India](government)(government of India) and the local [of Delhi](government)(government of Delhi), and serves as the capital of the nation as well as the NCT of Delhi. Delhi is also the centre of the National Capital Region, which is an "interstate regional planning" area created in 1985.

Delhi hosted the inaugural [Asian Games](1951)(1951 Asian Games), the [Asian Games](1982)(1982 Asian Games), the 1983 [Movement](Non-Aligned)(Non-Aligned Movement) summit, the [Men's Hockey World Cup](2010)(2010 Men's Hockey World Cup), the [Commonwealth Games](2010)(2010 Commonwealth Games), and the [BRICS summit](2012)(4th BRICS summit) and was one of the major host cities of the [Cricket World Cup](2011)(2011 Cricket World Cup).

**Delhi**;  *dillī*;  *dillī*;  *dêhlī*, informally  *dillī*),

*

*

*}}, officially the **National Capital Territory** (**NCT**) **of Delhi**, is a city and a [territory](union)(union territory) of [India](India) containing [Delhi](New)(New Delhi), the capital of India. Straddling the [Yamuna](Yamuna) river, primarily its western or right bank, Delhi shares borders with the state of [Pradesh](Uttar)(Uttar Pradesh) in the east and with the state of [Haryana](Haryana) in the remaining directions. The NCT covers an area of . According to the 2011 census, Delhi's city proper population was over 11 million, while the NCT's population was about 16.8 million. Delhi's urban agglomeration, which includes the satellite cities [Ghaziabad](Ghaziabad), [Faridabad](Faridabad), [Gurgaon](Gurgaon) and [Noida](Noida) in an area known as the [Capital Region](National)(National Capital Region (India)) (NCR), has an estimated population of over 28 million, making it the [metropolitan area in India](largest)(List of metropolitan areas in India) and the [in the world](second-largest)(List of urban areas by population) (after [Tokyo](Tokyo)).

The topography of the medieval fort [Qila](Purana)(Purana Qila) on the banks of the river Yamuna matches the literary description of the citadel [Indraprastha](Indraprastha) in the Sanskrit epic *[Mahabharata](Mahabharata)*; however, excavations in the area have revealed no signs of an ancient built environment. From the early 13th century until the mid-19th century, Delhi was the capital of two major empires, the [sultanate](Delhi)(Delhi sultanate) and the [Empire](Mughal)(Mughal Empire), which covered large parts of [Asia](South)(South Asia). All three [World Heritage Site](UNESCO)(UNESCO World Heritage Site)s in the city, the [Minar](Qutub)(Qutub Minar), [Tomb](Humayun's)(Humayun's Tomb), and the [Fort](Red)(Red Fort), belong to this period. Delhi was the early centre of [Sufism](Sufism) and [Qawwali](Qawwali) music.  The names of [Auliya](Nizamuddin)(Nizamuddin Auliya) and [Khusrau](Amir)(Amir Khusrau) are prominently associated with it. The [Khariboli](Khariboli) dialect of Delhi was part of a linguistic development that gave rise to the literature of [Urdu](Urdu) and [Standard Hindi](Modern)(Modern Standard Hindi). Major Urdu poets from Delhi include [Taqi Mir](Mir)(Mir Taqi Mir) and [Ghalib](Mirza)(Mirza Ghalib). Delhi was a major centre of the [Rebellion of 1857](Indian)(Indian Rebellion of 1857). In 1911, [Delhi](New)(New Delhi), a southern region within Delhi, became the capital of the [Indian Empire](British)(British Indian Empire).  During the [of India](Partition)(Partition of India) in 1947, Delhi was transformed from a Mughal city to a Punjabi one, losing two-thirds of its Muslim residents, in part due to the pressure brought to bear by arriving Hindu and Sikh refugees from western Punjab.

*

*  After independence in 1947, New Delhi continued as the capital of the [of India](Dominion)(Dominion of India), and after 1950 of the [of India](Republic)(Republic of India).

Delhi ranks [among the Indian states and union territories](fifth)(List of Indian states and territories by Human Development Index) in [development index](human)(human development index). Delhi has the [second-highest](List of Indian states and union territories by GDP per capita) [per capita](GDP)(Gross domestic product) in India (after [Goa](Goa)). Although a [territory](union)(union territory), the political administration of the NCT of Delhi today more closely resembles that of a [state](States of India) of India, with its own legislature, high court and an executive council of ministers headed by a [Minister](Chief)(Chief Minister of Delhi). New Delhi is jointly administered by the federal [of India](government)(government of India) and the local [of Delhi](government)(government of Delhi), and serves as the capital of the nation as well as the NCT of Delhi. Delhi is also the centre of the National Capital Region, which is an "interstate regional planning" area created in 1985.

Delhi hosted the inaugural [Asian Games](1951)(1951 Asian Games), the [Asian Games](1982)(1982 Asian Games), the 1983 [Movement](Non-Aligned)(Non-Aligned Movement) summit, the [Men's Hockey World Cup](2010)(2010 Men's Hockey World Cup), the [Commonwealth Games](2010)(2010 Commonwealth Games), and the [BRICS summit](2012)(4th BRICS summit) and was one of the major host cities of the [Cricket World Cup](2011)(2011 Cricket World Cup).
The monument in Delhi completed during the reign of Sultan Iltutmish in the 13th century that is a UNESCO World Heritage Site is the Qutub Minar.

## Controversies

*Fallout 76* Power Armor [edition](special)(special edition) drew controversy upon release. Bethesda advertised that the edition would include a [canvas](canvas) [bag](duffel)(duffel bag), but a [nylon](nylon) one was included instead. Responding to customer complaints, Bethesda claimed that the bag had to be changed due to unavailability of materials, and initially stated the intention to take no action. The publisher received criticism for not making the change known beforehand, with *[Eurogamer](Eurogamer)* pointing out that the bag's description on Bethesda's website had only changed to read "nylon" after complaints had been submitted. Bethesda later offered affected customers free in-game currency of 500 atoms as compensation, equivalent to . Critics pointed out this amount of currency was not enough to purchase the in-game postman uniform (700 atoms), which includes a canvas bag. Additionally, it was discovered that Bethesda had produced a different *Fallout 76*–themed canvas bag and given them for free to [influencers](online)(Internet celebrity), further adding to the fan outrage. Bethesda announced on December 3, 2018, that they would be producing canvas bags for all owners of the Power Armor special edition, which were ultimately said to be shipping "in four to six months." In June 2019, the bags were delivered to customers.

A [breach](data)(data breach) occurred on December 5, 2018, when a [glitch](glitch) in Bethesda's [system](support)(Issue tracking system) revealed personal information of approximately 65 *Fallout 76* customers who had submitted a support ticket to receive the canvas bag. Users were able to open and close tickets of other customers and view personal information, including names, addresses, emails and partial credit card information. In a statement given to *[Technica](Ars)(Ars Technica)*, Bethesda said that the breach occurred via "an error with our customer support website" and that they are "investigating the incident and will provide additional updates as we learn more". The publisher clarified that the only information leaked were details that the support site would have requested, rather than credit card numbers or passwords, and that they would notify all affected customers.

In 2018, Bethesda partnered with the Silver Screen Bottling Company to create "Nuka Dark Rum", an alcoholic beverage based on the in-game "Nuka-Cola Dark" introduced in the *[4: Nuka-World](Fallout)(Fallout 4: Nuka-World)* [add-on](Downloadable content). The rum was available to be pre-ordered in August 2018 for . While its release was expected to coincide with the launch of *Fallout 76*, the rum was delayed and was shipped instead in late December 2018. Upon receiving it, fans criticized the fact that the rum bottle advertised, previously expected to be a bottle in the missile-like shape of the in-game Nuka-Cola item, had turned out to be a standard glass bottle encased in a large plastic cover. The rum's asking price of $80 was subsequently condemned from expectations that the design would be of high quality, since none of the marketing had stated what the bottles would be made of.

In September 2019, collectible "Nuka Cola"–themed *Fallout* helmets produced by Chronicle Collectibles, of which only 32 of the 20,000 manufactured were sold, were recalled by the [Consumer Product Safety Commission](U.S.)(U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission) due to containing high levels of mold and posing a health risk. No incidents or injuries were reported. [GameStop](GameStop), which sold the helmets, notified all customers who had purchased a helmet and offered them a full refund.

In June 2022, a *Kotaku* article published reports from ten anonymous former employees of Bethesda and its parent company [Media](ZeniMax)(ZeniMax Media) of severe mismanagement during *Fallout 76*s development. The reports claimed that [crunch](Crunch (video games)) had been enforced, leading to an "exodus" of senior developers from the company. The loss of staff led to Bethesda borrowing developers working on [Studios](Arkane)(Arkane Studios)' *[Redfall](Redfall)* and Bethesda's *[Starfield](Starfield (video game))* to assist with *Fallout 76*. Other alleged issues included technical problems with the game's design and engine, as well as these concerns being ignored by senior management. The sources expressed cynicism towards an improvement of working conditions at Bethesda (following their acquisition by Microsoft), saying "It would be great if something like [ABetterABK](ABK Workers Alliance) existed for Bethesda [...] But everyone is terrified...because [Bethesda] HR is super cutthroat."

The controversy involving the Fallout 76 Power Armor edition's physical item centered around the packaging bag. Bethesda advertised that the edition would include a canvas duffel bag, but instead, a nylon bag was included. The decision to switch materials was due to unavailability, but Bethesda initially did not inform customers of this change. When complaints arose, Bethesda offered affected customers in-game currency as compensation, which critics argued was insufficient to purchase the in-game canvas bag. It was also revealed that Bethesda had produced and gifted a different canvas bag to influencers, further fueling fan outrage. Bethesda later announced they would produce and ship canvas bags to all owners of the Power Armor edition, which began arriving in June 2019.

# Fox Broadcasting Company

*Revision ID: 1159558620 | Timestamp: 2023-06-11T03:19:43Z*

---

| language = English

| former_names = FBC  (1986–1987)

| owner = [Corporation](Fox)(Fox Corporation)

| parent = [Entertainment](Fox)(Fox Entertainment)

| key_people = [Murdoch](Lachlan)(Lachlan Murdoch) (CEO)

The **Fox Broadcasting Company**,Corporate name as per:  ([full filing](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1308161/000119312513338522/0001193125-13-338522-index.htm)) commonly known simply as **Fox** and stylized in [caps](all)(all caps) as **FOX**, is an [American](Television in the United States) [commercial](Commercial broadcasting) [broadcast](terrestrial television) television network owned by [Corporation](Fox)(Fox Corporation) and headquartered in New York City, with master control operations and additional offices at the Fox Network Center in [Angeles](Los)(Los Angeles) and the Fox Media Center in [Tempe](Tempe, Arizona). Launched as a competitor to the [Three television networks](Big)(Big Three (American television)) ([ABC](American Broadcasting Company), [CBS](CBS), and [NBC](NBC)) on October 9, 1986, Fox went on to become the most successful attempt at a [television network](fourth)(fourth television network). It was the highest-[rated](Nielsen ratings) free-to-air network in the 18–49 demographic from 2004 to 2012 and again in 2020, and was the most-watched American television network in total viewership during the [season](2007–08)(2007–08 United States network television schedule).

Fox and its affiliated companies operate many entertainment channels in international markets, but these do not necessarily air the same programming as the U.S. network. Most viewers in Canada have access to at least one U.S.-based Fox affiliate, either over the air or through a pay television provider, although Fox's [Football League broadcasts](National)(NFL on Fox) and most of its prime time programming are subject to [substitution](simultaneous)(simultaneous substitution) regulations for [television](pay)(pay television) providers imposed by the [Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission](Canadian)(Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission) (CRTC) to protect rights held by domestically based networks.

Fox is named after the film studio that was originally called [Century Fox](20th)(20th Century Fox), and (indirectly) after the producer [Fox](William)(William Fox (producer)), who had founded one of the film studio's predecessors, [Film](Fox)(Fox Film), before it was merged with another company in 1935.  After it was purchased by [Murdoch](Rupert)(Rupert Murdoch)'s Australian conglomerate [Corporation](News)(News Corporation), the hyphen between "Century" and "Fox" was removed. (In 2013, its corporate sibling was split off as a stand-alone entertainment conglomerate, known as [Century Fox](21st)(21st Century Fox), which was [acquired](Acquisition of 21st Century Fox by Disney) in 2019 by [Walt Disney Company](The)(The Walt Disney Company).) Fox is a member of the [American Broadcasters Association](North)(North American Broadcasters Association) and the [Association of Broadcasters](National)(National Association of Broadcasters).
The show Bob's Burgers is broadcast on the Fox network.

# Moore's law

*Revision ID: 1160332713 | Timestamp: 2023-06-15T20:33:26Z*

---

[[File:Moore's Law Transistor Count 1970-2020.png|thumb|upright=2|A [plot](semi-log)(semi-log plot) of [count](transistor)(transistor count)s for [microprocessor](microprocessor)s against dates of introduction, nearly doubling every two years |alt=refer to caption|300px]]

'''Moore's law''' is the observation that the [of transistor](number)(Transistor count)s in an [circuit](integrated)(integrated circuit) (IC) doubles about every two years. Moore's law is an [observation](observation) and [projection](Forecasting) of a historical trend. Rather than a [of physics](law)(law of physics), it is an [relationship](empirical)(empirical relationship) linked to [from experience](gains)(Wright's Law) in production.

The observation is named after [Moore](Gordon)(Gordon Moore), the co-founder of [Semiconductor](Fairchild)(Fairchild Semiconductor) and [Intel](Intel) (and former CEO of the latter), who in 1965 posited a [every year](doubling)(exponential growth) in the number of components per integrated circuit, and projected this rate of growth would continue for at least another decade. In 1975, looking forward to the next decade, he revised the forecast to doubling every two years, a [annual growth rate](compound)(compound annual growth rate) (CAGR) of 41%. While Moore did not use empirical evidence in forecasting that the historical trend would continue, his prediction held since 1975 and has since become known as a "law".

Moore's prediction has been used in the [industry](semiconductor)(semiconductor industry) to guide long-term planning and to set targets for [and development](research)(research and development), thus functioning to some extent as a [prophecy](self-fulfilling)(self-fulfilling prophecy). Advancements in [electronics](digital)(digital electronics), such as the reduction in [quality-adjusted](Price index#Quality change) [microprocessor](microprocessor) prices, the increase in [capacity](memory)(Computer memory) ([RAM](Random-access memory) and [flash](flash memory)), the improvement of [sensors](digital sensor), and even the number and size of [pixel](pixel)s in [camera](digital)(digital camera)s, are strongly linked to Moore's law. These ongoing changes in digital electronics have been a driving force of technological and social change, [productivity](productivity), and economic growth.

Industry experts have not reached a consensus on exactly when Moore's law will cease to apply. Microprocessor architects report that semiconductor advancement has slowed industry-wide since around 2010, slightly below the pace predicted by Moore's law. In September 2022 [Nvidia](Nvidia) CEO [Huang](Jensen)(Jensen Huang) considered Moore's law dead, while Intel CEO [Gelsinger](Pat)(Pat Gelsinger) was of the opposite view.

## Plot

In a state penitentiary, social psychologist Dr. James Martin arrives to interrogate a notorious serial killer and death-row inmate named Edward. Before meeting Edward, Martin reveals to the warden, Moss, that he was brought in to fill in for Dr. Stewart, who was Edward's regular visitor for this procedure. Stewart had died by suicide the night before, causing Martin to replace him. Edward is scheduled to die via electrocution at his insistence that very day and Moss explains to Martin that Edward's fate depends upon Martin's diagnosis; if Martin deduces that Edward is sane, he will be executed, but if Martin declares him insane with multi-personality disorder as Stewart had believed, Edward will be spared.

When Martin takes a seat to interrogate Edward, the inmate refuses to be identified as a human and instead a demon inhabiting Edward's body named "Nefariamous," a name Satan gave him  "Nefarious" for short. Martin does not believe Nefarious is who he says he is and thinks instead that it is an act by Edward to seem insane; however, he is surprised when Nefarious insists that he wants to be executed, or rather, that he wants Edward to be executed. Nefarious also explains that before the day is over, Martin will commit three murders.

Martin, an atheist, balks at this idea but plays along, asking Nefarious how he came to inhabit Edward. Nefarious explains that he possessed Edward through a process carried out through Edward’s life, beginning with ease of access through Edward’s never having been [baptized](baptized), continuing through seemingly innocuous events such as Edward’s grandmother having given him a [board](ouija)(ouija board) as a present, allowing manipulative communication, finally completing the process only after Edward consented to the possession multiple times. Martin brings in a chaplain to confront the demon in Edward, which frightens Nefarious until he realizes that the priest does not believe in demons and therefore has no effect on him. Martin then asks to talk to Edward, causing Nefarious to recede and produce a timid, childlike Edward who is terribly distraught and shaken by his possession. Edward insists that he is possessed and that the demon had murdered multiple people using his innocent body as a vessel.

When Martin begins probing further, Nefarious takes control and insists that Martin euthanized his terminally ill mother to acquire her massive wealth. Martin becomes angry and threatens to leave the meeting, but changes his mind. When Martin decides to write Nefarious off as insane, Nefarious explains that Martin's girlfriend is pregnant, and because Martin threatened to leave her, she is terminating her pregnancy. Overcome with curiosity, Martin begs a kindly prison guard for access to a phone, which he uses to call the health clinic from where he realizes his girlfriend has just finished with the abortion. Nefarious cackles with glee, explaining to Martin that "all hell is rejoicing."

Martin still remains doubtful Nefarious is possessed, but is fully intrigued to hear what the inmate has to tell him. After Martin insists that the world is reclaiming the moral high ground, Nefarious laughs before telling him there is currently an influx of slavery and human trafficking which the demons are helping with. Nefarious then explains he wants Martin to write a book called *The Dark Gospel*, which is his Satanic equivalent to the Bible and will begin another world religion in servitude to demons. Martin is called away by Warden Moss who reveals to him that upon searching Edward's prison cell, they found documentation of Martin's life as Nefarious had done with all his other victims, as well as the dark gospel which Edward wrote, crediting it to Martin's name. Martin, now believing Edward is faking split personalities, confronts Nefarious about this. Nefarious breaks his own hand to slip free of one of the cuffs and seizes Martin, threatening to break his neck unless Martin begs for his life. Overcome with terror, Martin begs Nefarious to spare him to which Nefarious complies before being beaten down by the prison guards. Instinctively, Martin declares that Edward is sane, but not before being warned by a triumphant Nefarious that he is condemning Edward to death.

As Edward is in the electric chair, Nefarious possesses his body for a final time, asking if Martin accepts his offer, to which Martin silently refuses. Disappointed, Nefarious leaves Edward's body, causing Edward to suffer an extremely painful and terrible death in the chair. The demon then tells Martin, "You should have accepted my offer," before possessing him and trying to force Martin to commit suicide. However, Martin inadvertently prays to God for help, causing the gun to misfire and Nefarious to let go of him. One year later, a visibly changed Martin is shown promoting Nefarious' book  not as a "dark gospel" but as a rewritten cautionary tale for people to read and realize the demonic influence in society. On his way home, Martin bumps into a homeless woman whom Nefarious has now possessed.
The demon possessing the death-row inmate in the film Nefarious is named "Nefariamous," often referred to as "Nefarious" for short.

### 2018: Formation, EP, and tour

[[in 2018–2019](File:Boygenius.png|thumb|right|Boygenius)]

Bridgers has called the formation of the group "kind of an accident," wherein each of the members were simply fans of each other's work and then became friends. Both Dacus and Bridgers had opened for Baker on separate tours in 2016, and they all ran in similar circles as young up-and-coming performers navigating the [indie](Independent music) scene.

The three became close and shared their frustrations of constantly being compared to each other as "[in rock](women)(women in rock)" despite their considerably different musical styles. Dacus has commented that the idea of women in music "should not be remarkable whatsoever," with Bridgers adding, "it's not a genre." Each has spoken on the tendency of the music industry to pit women against each other, and the group was formed in part to reject this idea. "I hope people see the three of us and know there isn't competition," Dacus has said. "You don't have to compete with your contemporaries. You can make something good with people you admire."

Baker had joked to Dacus years before about a "pipe dream" that they could one day all form a band. The three decided to book a [tour](co-headlining)(Julien Baker and Phoebe Bridgers with Lucy Dacus Tour) in early 2018, and they originally planned to record a single or a [version](cover)(cover version) so that they could perform something together on stage. Upon meeting up that summer, however, they found themselves overwhelmed with ideas, and they ended up forming the band, writing, recording, and self-producing the *[Boygenius](Boygenius (EP))* [EP](Extended play) in four days, with the process involving almost exclusively women.

Each brought one full song and one incomplete idea with them to the group. They sought to create an environment free of the competitiveness and "bravado" they had often encountered in previous experiences, and they have remarked that the absence of adult men in the process proved significant, allowing them to relate to each other openly without constantly having to explain themselves. The record was met with universal acclaim from critics and audiences alike; it was named the 12th best album of 2018 by [Music](NPR)(NPR Music), despite being only an [EP](Extended play). Their subsequent [tour](Julien Baker and Phoebe Bridgers with Lucy Dacus Tour) that November saw them performing all across the U.S., as well as on *[Night with Seth Meyers](Late)(Late Night with Seth Meyers)* and the [Desk](Tiny)(List of Tiny Desk Concerts).
The three musicians who formed the indie rock supergroup boygenius in 2018 are Julien Baker, Phoebe Bridgers, and Lucy Dacus.

## Early life and education

O'Donnell was born in [D.C.](Washington,)(Washington, D.C.), the daughter of Noreen Bernadette (O'Kane) and Francis Lawrence O'Donnell, a [ medical doctor and](United States Army Medical Corps)  [Army](US)(US Army) officer.Stated on *[Your Roots](Finding)(Finding Your Roots)*, January 13, 2021 Her parents are both of Irish descent, with roots in [Derry](Derry), [Belfast](Belfast), and [Donegal](County Donegal) (meaning she is descended from both sides of the [Border](Irish)(Republic of Ireland–United Kingdom border)). Three of her grandparents were immigrants, and her maternal grandfather lived in the U.S. illegally for 16 years. When Norah was three, her family moved to [Antonio](San)(San Antonio), [Texas](Texas).[Impressive! S.A. TV alumna joins CBS News](http://blog.mysanantonio.com/jakle06/2015/06/impressive-s-a-tv-alumna-joins-cbs-news/#33701101=0) by Jeanne Jakle. *San Antonio Express-News*, June 16, 2015. Retrieved June 17, 2015. When she was 10, the family spent two years in [Seoul](Seoul), living in [Garrison](Yongsan)(Yongsan Garrison) as her father was assigned to work there.  While an elementary student, she started her career in broadcasting by giving videotaped English lessons for the Korean Educational Development Institute.[Norah O'Donnell revisits her childhood home in South Korea](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mwKUT9NkJkQ&t=3m31s) {CBS This Morning, posted to YouTube on Jun 22, 2017}  The family moved back to San Antonio, where she attended [MacArthur High School](Douglas)(Douglas MacArthur High School (San Antonio)), from which she graduated in 1991. She then went on to attend [University](Georgetown)(Georgetown University), where she graduated in 1995 with a [of Arts](Bachelor)(Bachelor of Arts) degree in [philosophy](philosophy) and a [of Arts](Master)(Master of Arts) degree in [studies](liberal)(liberal studies) in 2003.[Norah O'Donnell Guest Speaker](http://washingtonpostlive.com/conferences/speakers/norah-odonnell)  WashingtonPostLive.com
Norah O'Donnell was born in Washington, D.C.

### Voice work

[[Rhys-Davies (7979439918).jpg|thumb|170px|Rhys-Davies in September 2012](File:John)]

In addition to voicing the Ent [Treebeard](Treebeard) in *Lord of the Rings*, Rhys-Davies has lent his distinctive voice to many video games and animated television series, including the role of [Hades](Hades (DC Comics)) in *[League](Justice)(Justice League (TV series))*, the original voice of [Ray](Man)(List of SpongeBob SquarePants characters#Man Ray) in *[SquarePants](SpongeBob)(SpongeBob SquarePants)* (until both roles were recast to [Joles](Bob)(Bob Joles)), and numerous times in *[Gargoyles](Gargoyles (TV series))* (1994–1996), as the character [Macbeth](Macbeth (Gargoyles)). He also lent his vocal talents to the games *[Freelancer](Freelancer (video game))* (as Richard Winston Tobias) and *[of Everquest](Lords)(Lords of Everquest)* (both in 2003) and the game *[for Glory IV: Shadows of Darkness](Quest)(Quest for Glory IV: Shadows of Darkness)*, which was released with his narration on a CD-ROM version in 1995. He also had a voice role on ''[Gate: Dark Alliance](Baldur's)(Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance)* as the character Jherek, and narrated a documentary called *The Glory of Macedonia*. [Generation](Next)(Next Generation (magazine)) magazine gave its *[2000](Dune)(Dune 2000)'' review 'an automatic one-star deduction for featuring John "Multimedia Whore" Rhys-Davies in the [FMV](Full motion video).'

John Rhys-Davies' voice can be heard on the 2009 documentary *[The Blade](Reclaiming)(Reclaiming The Blade)*. In the narration, Rhys-Davies explores swords, [European swordsmanship](historical)(Historical European martial arts) and fight choreography on film, a topic very familiar to him from his experiences in *The Lord of the Rings* trilogy, where his character wielded an axe in many scenes.

In 2004, he was the unknowing subject of an internet prank that spread false rumours in several mainstream media sources that he was scheduled to play the role of [Grievous](General)(General Grievous) in *[Wars Episode III](Star)(Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith)*.

Rhys-Davies is the narrator of *The Truth & Life Dramatized audio New Testament Bible*, a 22-hour, celebrity-voiced, fully dramatised [audiobook](audiobook) version of the New Testament which uses the Revised Standard Version-Catholic Edition translation. In 2011, he presented *KJB: The Book That Changed The World*, which features him reading diverse snippets from the King James Version.

John Rhys-Davies’ voice work also includes voice-over work with *Breathe Bible*.[John Rhys-Davies, Narrator](http://breathebible.com/voices/john-rhys-davies/) BreatheBible.com Retrieved 19 September 2017.

In 2016, he provided spoken words for *[of Fire](Voices)(Voices of Fire)*, the sixth album by [cappella](a)(a cappella) [metal](power)(power metal) band [Canto](van)(van Canto).

A resident of the [of Man](Isle)(Isle of Man) since 1988, John Rhys-Davies provides the introductory voice-over to the Island's [Rushen](Castle)(Castle Rushen), one of the best-preserved medieval fortresses in the British Isles. In 2018, he lent his voice to the Isle of Man's tourism commercial.

Rhys-Davies voice was recorded for some of the callouts in the 1993 Williams SuperPin *Indiana Jones: The Pinball Adventure*
The actor who voiced the character Rooster, the Welsh Sheepdog, in The Secret Life of Pets 2 is John Rhys-Davies.

*Revision ID: 1159634993 | Timestamp: 2023-06-11T15:26:09Z*

***Poor Things*** is an upcoming [surrealist](Surrealist cinema) [fiction film](science)(science fiction film) directed by [Lanthimos](Yorgos)(Yorgos Lanthimos) from a screenplay by [McNamara](Tony)(Tony McNamara (writer)), based on the [novel of the same name](1992)(Poor Things) by [Gray](Alasdair)(Alasdair Gray). It follows a young woman who, after being [resurrected](Resurrection) by an unorthodox scientist, lives a life free of the prejudices of her time. [Stone](Emma)(Emma Stone) leads an [cast](ensemble)(ensemble cast) that includes [Ruffalo](Mark)(Mark Ruffalo), [Dafoe](Willem)(Willem Dafoe), [Youssef](Ramy)(Ramy Youssef), [Carmichael](Jerrod)(Jerrod Carmichael), [Abbott](Christopher)(Christopher Abbott), [Qualley](Margaret)(Margaret Qualley), and [Hunter](Kathryn)(Kathryn Hunter).

*Poor Things* is scheduled to be theatrically released on September 8, 2023, by [Pictures](Searchlight)(Searchlight Pictures).
"Poor Things" is based on a novel of the same name by Alasdair Gray.

## Charitable activity

The company gives 5% of annual pretax earnings to causes in the areas in which it operates, including education and food banks. The Excellence in Education Awards are an annual charitable program maintained by H-E-B since 2000, in which teachers, administrators and schools in Texas are recognized, with awards totaling $500,000 in contributions in 2009.

H-E-B coordinated donations to relief efforts in the wake of a [plant fire and explosion](fertilizer)(West Fertilizer Company explosion) in [Texas](West,)(West, Texas). The company donated $50,000 to the [Red Cross](American)(American Red Cross) and launched a checkstand campaign benefiting the organization to get the community involved in the relief effort. The company said in a news release 100% of the donations from the campaign will support the American Red Cross's disaster relief efforts. H-E-B also activated its emergency response units, sending the H-E-B Eddie Garcia Mobile Kitchen and water tanker to West, including donations of meals and water to the victims and first responders.

In the aftermath of [Harvey](Hurricane)(Hurricane Harvey) in 2017, H-E-B donated $100,000 toward relief efforts. Its campaign drive for customer contributions totaled $1,000,000. In addition, H-E-B's Mobile Kitchen and Disaster Relief Units distributed 10,000 hot meals to volunteers and victims in the affected areas in Texas.

After the [Elementary School shooting](Robb)(Robb Elementary School shooting) in [Texas](Uvalde,)(Uvalde, Texas), on May 24, 2022, in which 19 children and two teachers were killed, H-E-B and the Butt family donated $10 million toward building a new school as founding donors. Initial participants joining the family include Texas architectural firm, Huckabee, and Texas general contractor, Joeris General Contractors.
H-E-B donates 5% of its annual pretax earnings to various causes, including education and food banks.

## Music

The single 'Leeds United' was released in April 1972 to coincide with the team reaching the 1972 FA Cup Final, composed by [Reed](Les)(Les Reed (songwriter)) and [Mason](Barry)(Barry Mason) with the team providing the vocals. The record stayed in the [Singles Chart](UK)(UK Singles Chart) for almost three months, peaking at number 10. The B-side [Leeds! Leeds!']('Leeds!)(Marching On Together) (commonly known as *Marching on Together*) has since become the club's anthem and is regularly sung by supporters.
The song known as the anthem regularly sung by Leeds United supporters is "Marching on Together".

### Kherson Oblast

[[File:Meeting of the Council for Civil Society and Human Rights 2019-12-10 (7).jpg|thumb|[Kiriyenko](Sergey)(Sergey Kiriyenko) (left) became Putin's point man in the Russian-occupied territories of Ukraine.]]

: *Read more: [occupation of Kherson Oblast](Russian)(Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast)*

On February 24, 2022, Russian troops from Crimea invaded [Henichesk](Henichesk Raion) and [Skadovsk](Skadovsk Raion) Raions. During the first days of the offensive, the Russians surrounded most of the cities and towns in the oblast, blocking the entrances to them with roadblocks, but not entering the cities themselves. Significant battles were fought for the [Bridge](Antonivskyi)(Antonivka Road Bridge), which crosses the [River](Dnipro)(Dnieper) between Russian positions on the South bank and the Ukrainian city of [Kherson](Kherson) on the North bank. The Russian military's overwhelming firepower forced the Ukrainian forces to retreat, and the city [to Russian control](fell)(Battle of Kherson) on March 2. On June 29, the [occupation authorities in Kherson Oblast](Russian)(Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast) announced preparations for holding a [of annexation](referendum)(2022 Russian-occupied Ukraine annexation referendums). On July 9, the Ukrainian government announced preparations for an [counteroffensive in the South](imminent)(2022 Kherson counteroffensive), and urged the residents of occupied parts of [Kherson](Kherson Oblast) and [Zaporizhzhia](Zaporizhzhia Oblast) Oblasts to shelter or evacuate to minimize civilian casualties in the operation. Following the destruction of the Antonivskyi Bridge and the advance of Ukrainian troops from the west, the lack of sustainable supply lines amid heavy Ukrainian shelling compelled the Russian forces to retreat. They eventually retreated from all areas on the North bank of the [River](Dnipro)(Dnieper), including the city of Kherson, which the Ukrainian forces recaptured soon after, known as the [of Kherson](liberation)(liberation of Kherson).

[[File:Kherson after Russian shelling, 2023-01-15 (02).jpg|thumb|Liberated [Kherson](Kherson) after shelling by the Russian army on 15 January 2023]]

[Raions](Raions of Ukraine) of [Oblast](Kherson)(Kherson Oblast) that are occupied:

* [Raion](Henichesk)(Henichesk Raion)

* [Raion](Kakhovka)(Kakhovka Raion)

* [Raion](Skadovsk)(Skadovsk Raion)

* Half of [Raion](Kherson)(Kherson Raion)
The Ukrainian city that was recaptured by Ukrainian forces on 11 November 2022 during the Kherson counteroffensive is Kherson.

# Miles Teller

*Revision ID: 1159837845 | Timestamp: 2023-06-12T21:15:25Z*

---

| birth_place        = [Pennsylvania](Pennsylvania), U.S.

| alma_mater         = [York University](New)(New York University) ([BFA](Bachelor of Fine Arts))

| spouse             =

| occupation         = Actor

| years_active       = 2004–present

}}

**Miles Teller** (born February 20, 1987) is an American actor. He made his feature film debut with the independent drama *[Hole](Rabbit)(Rabbit Hole (2010 film))* (2010), and gained recognition for his starring role in the coming-of-age film *[Spectacular Now](The)(The Spectacular Now)* (2013) and the [film trilogy](*Divergent*)(The Divergent Series) (2014–2016), both opposite [Woodley](Shailene)(Shailene Woodley). His starring role in the drama *[Whiplash](Whiplash (2014 film))* (2014) served as his breakthrough and earned him praise. He went on to star in the superhero film *[Four](Fantastic)(Fantastic Four (2015 film))* (2015) and the biographical film *[Dogs](War)(War Dogs (2016 film))* (2016).

Teller gained wider success for starring in the action film *[Gun: Maverick](Top)(Top Gun: Maverick)* (2022). On television, he has starred in the [Prime Video](Amazon)(Amazon Prime Video) crime drama *[Old to Die Young](Too)(Too Old to Die Young)* (2019) and the [Paramount+](Paramount+) miniseries *[Offer](The)(The Offer)* (2022).
Miles Teller attended the University of Southern California for his Bachelor of Fine Arts degree.

## Cards

American Express executives discussed the possibility of launching a travel [card](charge)(charge card) as early as 1946, but it was not until [Club](Diners)(Diners Club) launched a card in March 1950, that American Express began to seriously consider the possibility. At the end of 1957, American Express CEO [Reed](Ralph)(Ralph Reed (American Express)) decided to get into the card business, and by the launch date of October 1, 1958, public interest had become so significant that 250,000 cards were issued prior to the official launch date. The card was launched with an annual fee of $6, $1 higher than Diners Club, to be seen as a premium product. The first cards were made of paper, with the account number and card member's name typed. In 1959, American Express began issuing embossed plastic cards, an industry first., the company had 133.3 million cards in force, including 56.4million cards in force in the United States, each with average annual spending of $23,496. These include consumer, small business and corporate cards issued by American Express themselves and cards issued by its Global Service Network partners that run on its network (such as Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, and NAB in Australia and Lloyds Bank and Barclays Bank in the UK). On March 1, 2017, Australia's fourth-largest bank ANZ announced that it was no longer issuing American Express cards, with the support phased out entirely by August 5, 2017. American Express is the fourth largest general-purpose card network on a global basis based on purchase volume, behind China UnionPay, Visa and MasterCard. It is the 4th largest card network in the world, based on the number of cards it has in circulation. American Express is one of the partner banks to both [Google](Google) and [Apple](Apple Inc.)'s mobile wallet systems ([Pay](Google)(Google Wallet) and [Pay](Apple)(Apple Pay), respectively) meaning that cardholders can use their American Express-issued cards to pay at establishments where [NFC](Near field communication) payments are accepted. American Express offers various [credit cards](contactless)(Contactless smart card).
The American Express card introduced in 1999 that is often referred to as the 'black card' is the American Express Centurion Card, commonly known as the "Black Card."

# The Town (2010 film)

*Revision ID: 1160293959 | Timestamp: 2023-06-15T15:02:25Z*

***The Town*** is a 2010 American [crime](Crime film) [drama](Drama (film and television)) film co-written, directed by, and starring [Affleck](Ben)(Ben Affleck), adapted from [Hogan](Chuck)(Chuck Hogan)'s 2004 novel *Prince of Thieves*. It also stars [Hall](Rebecca)(Rebecca Hall), [Hamm](Jon)(Jon Hamm), [Renner](Jeremy)(Jeremy Renner), [Lively](Blake)(Blake Lively), [Welliver](Titus)(Titus Welliver), [Postlethwaite](Pete)(Pete Postlethwaite), [Cooper](Chris)(Chris Cooper) and [Slaine](Slaine (rapper)), and follows a [Boston](Boston) [robber](bank)(Bank robbery) who begins to develop romantic feelings for a victim of one of his previous robberies, while he and his crew set out to get one final score by robbing [Park](Fenway)(Fenway Park).

The film premiered on September 8, 2010, at the [Film Festival](Venice)(Venice Film Festival) before being released in the United States on September 17, 2010. Based on actual events, it received praise from critics for its direction, screenplay, editing, and the performances of the cast (particularly Renner) and grossed $154 million worldwide. The film was chosen by the [Board of Review](National)(National Board of Review) as one of the [ten films of 2010](top)(National Board of Review Awards 2010#Top 10 Films), while Renner was nominated for the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor) and Postlethwaite was posthumously nominated for the [Award for Best Supporting Actor](BAFTA)(BAFTA Award for Best Supporting Actor).
Ben Affleck directed, co-wrote, and starred in the 2010 crime drama film "The Town".

## The play called *The King in Yellow*

The fictional play *The King in Yellow* has at least two acts and at least three characters: Cassilda, Camilla and "the Stranger", who may or may not be the titular character.

Chambers' story collection excerpts some sections from the play to introduce the book as a whole, or individual stories. For example, "Cassilda's Song" comes from Act 1, Scene 2 of the play:"The King in Yellow" in e.g.

The short story "The Mask" is introduced by an excerpt from Act 1, Scene 2d:"The Mask" in e.g.

It is also stated, in "The Repairer of Reputations", that the final moment of the first act involves the character Camilla's "agonized scream and [...] awful words echoing through the dim streets of Carcosa".

All of the excerpts come from Act I. The stories describe Act I as quite ordinary, but reading Act II drives the reader mad with the "irresistible" revealed truths: "The very banality and innocence of the first act only allowed the blow to fall afterward with more awful effect". Even seeing the first page of the second act is enough to draw the reader in: "If I had not caught a glimpse of the opening words in the second act I should never have finished it" ("[Repairer of Reputations](The)(The Repairer of Reputations)").

Chambers usually gives only scattered hints of the contents of the full play, as in this extract from "The Repairer of Reputations":

He mentioned the establishment of the Dynasty in Carcosa, the lakes which connected Hastur, Aldebaran and the mystery of the Hyades. He spoke of Cassilda and Camilla, and sounded the cloudy depths of Demhe, and the Lake of Hali. "The scolloped tatters of the King in Yellow must hide Yhtill forever", he muttered, but I do not believe Vance heard him. Then by degrees he led Vance along the ramifications of the Imperial family, to Uoht and Thale, from Naotalba and Phantom of Truth, to Aldones, and then tossing aside his manuscript and notes, he began the wonderful story of the Last King.

A similar passage occurs in "The Yellow Sign", in which two protagonists have read *The King in Yellow*:

Night fell and the hours dragged on, but still we murmured to each other of the King and the Pallid Mask, and midnight sounded from the misty spires in the fog-wrapped city. We spoke of Hastur and of Cassilda, while outside the fog rolled against the blank window-panes as the cloud waves roll and break on the shores of Hali.

The fictional play within 'The King in Yellow' that induces despair or madness is called *The King in Yellow*. Reading the second act of this play is said to drive the reader mad with the "irresistible" revealed truths, and even glimpsing the first page of the second act can be enough to ensnare the reader.

### 2021–present: *Desire, I Want to Turn Into You*

[[Polachek - First Avenue 12-7-2021 45.jpg|thumb|right|Polachek performing in 2021](File:Caroline)]

In September 2021, Polachek was announced as one of the opening acts on [Lipa](Dua)(Dua Lipa)'s [Nostalgia Tour](Future)(Future Nostalgia Tour). The tour began on February 9, 2022. On November 4, 2021, Charli XCX released "[Shapes](New)(New Shapes)" featuring Christine and the Queens and Polachek as the second single from her studio album *[Crash](Crash (Charli XCX album))* (2022).

On July 14, 2021, Polachek released the single "[Is a Rider](Bunny)(Bunny Is a Rider)", another collaboration with Harle; she told *[Crack](Crack (magazine))* magazine that the song was part of a future project. In December, *[Pitchfork](Pitchfork (website))* ranked "Bunny Is a Rider" at the top of their list of "The 100 Best Songs of 2021". On February 9, 2022, Polachek released the single "[Billions](Billions (Caroline Polachek song))". In March, she was featured on Australian electronic music producer [Flume](Flume (musician))'s single "Sirens", released ahead of his upcoming studio album [*Palaces*](Palaces (album)). In June, Polachek confirmed that she was working on her fourth studio album, posting a picture of herself in studio with Danny L Harle on [Instagram](Instagram). She recorded a cover version of "[Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)](Bang)(Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down))" for the [The Rise of Gru* soundtrack album](*Minions:)(Minions: The Rise of Gru (soundtrack)), released on July 1, 2022. On October 17, her flamenco-inspired single "Sunset", a co-production with [Bodega](Sega)(Sega Bodega), was released.

On December 5, 2022, Polachek released the single "[to My Island](Welcome)(Welcome to My Island)" and announced her second studio album under her full name, *[I Want to Turn Into You](Desire,)(Desire, I Want to Turn Into You)*, for release on February 14, 2023. The album received critical acclaim and includes "Bunny Is a Rider", "Billions", "Sunset", and "Welcome to My Island".
The album Caroline Polachek released in 2023 that received critical acclaim and includes the single "Bunny Is a Rider" is titled *I Want to Turn Into You*.

**Playground Games Limited** is a British [game developer](video)(video game developer) based in [Spa](Leamington)(Leamington Spa), England. It is known for developing the *[Horizon](Forza)(Forza#Horizon)* series, which is part of the larger *[Forza](Forza)* franchise. In 2018, Playground Games became part of [Studios](Microsoft)(Microsoft Studios) (now known as Xbox Game Studios). They are also developing the next game in the *[Fable](Fable (video game series))* series.

# List of largest cruise ships

*Revision ID: 1158022562 | Timestamp: 2023-06-01T13:42:21Z*

---

[[File:Wonder of the Seas - August 2021.png|thumb|right|*[of the Seas](Wonder)(Wonder of the Seas)* is the latest ship of Royal Caribbean's  of cruise ships.]]

[ship](Cruise)(Cruise ship)s are large [ship](passenger)(passenger ship)s used mainly for vacationing. Unlike [liner](ocean)(ocean liner)s, they typically embark on round-trip voyages to various ports-of-call, where passengers may go on [tours](Tourism) known as "shore excursions". They may carry thousands of passengers in a single trip, and are some of the largest ships in the world by the [tonnage](gross)(gross tonnage)(GT), bigger than many [ships](cargo)(List of largest container ships). Cruise ships started to exceed ocean liners in size and capacity in the mid-1990s; before then, few were more than 50,000GT. In the decades since, the size of the largest vessels has more than doubled. There have been nine or more new cruise ships added every year since 2001, most of which are 100,000GT or greater. In the two decades between 1988 and 2009, the largest cruise ships grew a third longer (268 m to 360 m), almost doubled their widths (32.2 m to 60.5 m), doubled the total passengers (2,744 to 5,400), and tripled in volume (73,000 GT to 225,000 GT). , the largest cruise ship, , has a gross tonnage of 236,857, is  long,  wide, and holds up to 6,988 passengers.

Cruise ships are organized much like floating hotels, with a complete hospitality staff in addition to the usual ship's crew. Modern cruise ships, while sacrificing some qualities of [seaworthiness](seakeeping), have added amenities to cater to [tourists](nautical)(nautical tourism), with recent vessels being described as "balcony-laden floating condominiums". The "megaships" went from a single deck with verandas to all decks with verandas, and feature ameneties such as theaters, fine-dining and chain restaurants, spas, fitness centers, casinos, sports facilities, and even amusement park attractions.

Cruise ships require electricity for powering both hotel services and for [propulsion](Marine propulsion). Cruise ships are designed with all the heavy machinery at the bottom of the ship and lightweight materials at the top, making them inherently stable even as ship designs are getting taller and taller, and most passenger ships utilize [fins](stabilizer)(Stabilizer (ship)) to further reduce rolling of tall ships in heavy weather. While some cruise ships use traditional fixed [propeller](propeller)s and [rudder](rudder)s to steer, most larger ships use propellers that can swivel left and right to steer the ship, known as [thruster](azimuth)(azimuth thruster)s, which allow even the largest ship designs to have adequate maneuverability.

Cruise ships are operated by [line](cruise)(cruise line)s, which are [companies](company) that market cruises to the public. In the 1990s, many cruise lines were bought by much larger holding companies and continue to operate as brands or subsidiaries of the holding company. For instance, [Corporation & plc](Carnival)(Carnival Corporation & plc) owns both the [mass-market](Mass market) [Cruise Line](Carnival)(Carnival Cruise Line), focused on larger party ships for younger travelers, and [America Line](Holland)(Holland America Line), whose smaller ships cultivate an image of classic elegance. The common practice in the cruise industry in ship sales and orders is to list the smaller operating company, not the larger holding corporation, as the recipient cruise line of the ship.
As of 2023, the largest cruise ship by gross tonnage is the **Wonder of the Seas**. It has a gross tonnage of approximately **236,857 GT**.

*Revision ID: 1158837261 | Timestamp: 2023-06-06T14:58:35Z*

(split in two parts in 1960, renamed to Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd in 1962)

| founders = [Karl](Karl Albrecht) and [Albrecht](Theo)(Theo Albrecht)

| location = [Essen](Essen), Germany (Aldi Nord) [Mülheim](Mülheim), Germany (Aldi Süd)

**Aldi** (stylised as **ALDI**) is the common company brand name of two German multinational family-owned [supermarket](discount)(discount supermarket) [chains](Chain store) operating over 10,000 stores in 20 countries. The chain was founded by brothers [Karl](Karl Albrecht) and [Albrecht](Theo)(Theo Albrecht) in 1946, when they took over their mother's store in [Essen](Essen). The business was split into two separate groups in 1960, that later became **Aldi Nord**, headquartered in [Essen](Essen), and **Aldi Süd**, headquartered in [Mülheim](Mülheim an der Ruhr)."[Impressum](http://www.aldi-nord.de/impressum.html)" Aldi Nord. Retrieved on 14 February 2011. "Aldi Einkauf GmbH & Co. oHG Eckenbergstraße 16 45307 Essen.""[Impressum](http://www.aldi-sud.de/de/html/impressum.htm) ." Aldi Süd. Retrieved on 14 February 2011. "Burgstraße 37 45476 Mülheim an der Ruhr Amtsgericht Duisburg HRA 8577."

In 1962, they introduced the name **Aldi** (a [abbreviation](syllabic)(syllabic abbreviation) for **Al**brecht **Di**skont), which is pronounced . In Germany, Aldi Nord and Aldi Süd have been financially and legally separate since 1966, although both divisions' names may appear as if they were a single enterprise with certain [brand](store)(store brand)s or when negotiating with [contractor](General contractor) companies. The formal business name of Aldi Nord is Aldi Einkauf GmbH & Co., while the formal business name of Aldi Süd is ALDI SÜD Dienstleistungs-SE & Co.  Each company is owned and operated independently, but do have contractual business with one another.

Aldi's German operations consist of Aldi Nord's 35 individual regional companies with about 2,500 stores in western, northern, and eastern Germany, and Aldi Süd's 32 regional companies with 1,900 stores in western and southern Germany. How Does Aldi Make Money  Strategy and Insights – Vizologi  rethinking business model design|date=13 December 2017|work=Vizologi  rethinking business model design|access-date=5 July 2018}} Internationally, Aldi Nord operates in [Denmark](Denmark), [France](France), the [Benelux](Benelux) countries, [Portugal](Portugal), [Spain](Spain) and [Poland](Poland), while Aldi Süd operates in [Ireland](Republic of Ireland), the [Kingdom](United)(United Kingdom), [Hungary](Hungary), [Switzerland](Switzerland), [Australia](Australia), [China](China), [Italy](Italy), [Austria](Austria) and [Slovenia](Slovenia). Both Aldi Nord (owner of [Joe's](Trader)(Trader Joe's)) and Aldi Süd (as Aldi) also operate in the [States](United)(United States) with 1,600 stores between them as of 2017, and the U.S. is the only country to have both Aldi companies operating outside of Germany.
The name 'Aldi' is an abbreviation for the German words "Albrecht" and "Di" (discount), which together stand for "Albrecht Discount."

# Unicursal hexagram

*Revision ID: 1154828308 | Timestamp: 2023-05-14T22:37:52Z*

---

[[unicursal hexagram.svg|upright|thumb|Non-interlaced unicursal hexagram](File:Solid)]

The **unicursal hexagram** is a [hexagram](hexagram) or six-pointed star that can be traced or drawn [unicursally](unicursal curve), in one continuous line rather than by two overlaid triangles. The hexagram can also be depicted inside a circle with the points touching it. It is often depicted in an interlaced form with the lines of the hexagram passing over and under one another to form a [knot](knot (mathematics)). It is a specific instance of the far more general shape discussed in [Pascal](Blaise)(Blaise Pascal)'s 1639 *[Mysticum](Hexagrammum)(Hexagrammum Mysticum)*.
The unicursal hexagram is an example of a specific shape discussed in Blaise Pascal's 1639 work titled "Hexagrammum Mysticum."

## Conservation status, threats, and controversies

[[File:Polar Bear Habitat.png|thumb|upright=1.5|Map from the [Geological Survey](U.S.)(U.S. Geological Survey) shows projected changes in polar bear habitat from 2001 to 2010 and 2041 to 2050. Red areas indicate loss of optimal polar bear habitat; blue areas indicate gain.]]

Polar bear population sizes and trends are difficult to estimate accurately because they occupy remote home ranges and exist at low population densities. Polar bear fieldwork can also be hazardous to researchers. As of 2015, the [Union for Conservation of Nature](International)(International Union for Conservation of Nature) (IUCN) reports that the global population of polar bears is 22,000 to 31,000, and the current population trend is unknown. Nevertheless, polar bears are listed as "Vulnerable" under criterion A3c, which indicates an expected population decrease of ≥30% over the next three generations (~34.5 years) due to "decline in area of occupancy, extent of occurrence and/or quality of habitat". Risks to the polar bear include [change](climate)(climate change), [pollution](pollution) in the form of [toxic](toxic) contaminants, conflicts with shipping, oil and gas exploration and development, and human-bear interactions including harvesting and possible stresses from recreational polar-bear watching.

According to the [Wildlife Fund](World)(World Wildlife Fund), the polar bear is important as an [indicator](indicator species) of Arctic [health](ecosystem)(ecosystem health). Polar bears are studied to gain understanding of what is happening throughout the Arctic, because at-risk polar bears are often a sign of something wrong with the Arctic [ecosystem](marine)(marine ecosystem).[WWF: A Leader in Polar Bear Conservation](http://www.worldwildlife.org/species/finder/polarbear/polarbear.html#). Retrieved: 1 August 2015.

#### Canada

[[File:Dogsledquebec.jpg|thumb|[Dogsled](Dogsled)s are used for recreational hunting of polar bears in [Canada](Canada)]]

Polar bears were designated "Not at Risk" in April 1986 and uplisted to "Special Concern" in April 1991. This status was re-evaluated and confirmed in April 1999, November 2002, and April 2008. Polar bears continue to be listed as a species of special concern in Canada because of their sensitivity to overharvest and because of an expected range contraction caused by loss of Arctic sea ice.

More than 600 bears are killed per year by humans across Canada, a rate calculated by scientists to be unsustainable for some areas, notably [Bay](Baffin)(Baffin Bay). Canada has allowed sport hunters accompanied by local guides and dog-sled teams since 1970, but the practice was not common until the 1980s. The guiding of sport hunters provides meaningful employment and an important source of income for northern communities in which economic opportunities are few. Sport hunting can bring CDN$20,000 to $35,000 per bear into northern communities, which until recently has been mostly from American hunters.

The territory of [Nunavut](Nunavut) accounts for the location 80% of annual kills in Canada. In 2005, the government of Nunavut increased the quota from 400 to 518 bears, despite protests from the IUCN Polar Bear Specialist Group. In two areas where harvest levels have been increased based on increased sightings, science-based studies have indicated declining populations, and a third area is considered data-deficient. While most of that quota is hunted by the indigenous Inuit, a growing share is sold to recreational hunters. (0.8% in the 1970s, 7.1% in the 1980s, and 14.6% in the 1990s) Nunavut polar bear biologist, [Taylor](Mitchell)(Mitchell Taylor), who was formerly responsible for polar bear conservation in the territory, has insisted that bear numbers are being sustained under current hunting limits. In 2010, the 2005 increase was partially reversed. Government of Nunavut officials announced that the polar bear quota for the Baffin Bay region would be gradually reduced from 105 per year to 65 by 2013. The Government of the [Territories](Northwest)(Northwest Territories) maintain their own quota of 72 to 103 bears within the [Inuvialuit](Inuvialuit) communities of which some are set aside for sports hunters. [Canada](Environment)(Environment Canada) also banned the export from Canada of fur, claws, skulls and other products from polar bears harvested in Baffin Bay as of 1 January 2010.

Because of the way polar bear hunting quotas are managed in Canada, attempts to discourage sport hunting would actually increase the number of bears killed in the short term. Canada allocates a certain number of permits each year to sport and subsistence hunting, and those that are not used for sport hunting are re-allocated to indigenous subsistence hunting. Whereas northern communities kill all the polar bears they are permitted to take each year, only half of sport hunters with permits actually manage to kill a polar bear. If a sport hunter does not kill a polar bear before his or her permit expires, the permit cannot be transferred to another hunter.

In August 2011, [Canada](Environment)(Environment Canada) published a national polar bear conservation strategy.[National Polar Bear Conservation Strategy for Canada](http://www.ec.gc.ca/nature/default.asp?Lang=En&n=60D0FDBD-1)

#### Greenland

In Greenland, hunting restrictions were first introduced in 1994 and expanded by executive order in 2005. Until 2005 Greenland placed no limit on hunting by indigenous people. However, in 2006 it imposed a limit of 150, while also allowed recreational hunting for the first time.Rose, Naomi A. (16 February 2006) [Hitting Polar Bears When They Are Down](https://web.archive.org/web/20120321162633/http://www.hsi.org/news/news/2006/Hitting_polar_bears_when_down_021606.html). The Humane Society of the United States. Other provisions included year-round protection of cubs and mothers, restrictions on weapons used and various administrative requirements to catalogue kills.

#### Norway

Polar bears were hunted heavily in Svalbard, Norway throughout the 19th century and to as recently as 1973, when the conservation treaty was signed. 900 bears a year were harvested in the 1920s and after World War II, there were as many as 400–500 harvested annually. Some regulations of hunting did exist. In 1927, poisoning was outlawed while in 1939, certain denning sights were declared off limits. The killing of females and cubs was made illegal in 1965. Killing of polar bears decreased somewhat 25–30 years before the treaty. Despite this, the polar bear population continued to decline and by 1973, only around 1000 bears were left in Svalbard. Only with the passage of the treaty did they begin to recover.

#### Russia

The Soviet Union banned the harvest of polar bears in 1956; however, [poaching](poaching) continued, and is estimated to pose a serious threat to the polar bear population. In recent years, polar bears have approached coastal villages in Chukotka more frequently due to the shrinking of the sea ice, endangering humans and raising concerns that illegal hunting would become even more prevalent. In 2007, the Russian government made subsistence hunting legal for indigenous Chukotkan peoples only, a move supported by Russia's most prominent bear researchers and the [Wide Fund for Nature](World)(World Wide Fund for Nature) as a means to curb poaching.

Polar bears are currently listed as "Rare", of "Uncertain Status", or "Rehabilitated and rehabilitating" in the [Data Book of Russia](Red)(Red Data Book of Russia), depending on population. In 2010, the [of Natural Resources and Environment](Ministry)(Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Russia)) published a strategy for polar bear conservation in Russia.

#### United States

The [Mammal Protection Act of 1972](Marine)(Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972) afforded polar bears some protection in the United States. It banned hunting (except by indigenous subsistence hunters), banned importing of polar bear parts (except polar bear pelts taken legally in Canada), and banned the harassment of polar bears. On 15 May 2008, the [States Department of the Interior](United)(United States Department of the Interior) listed the polar bear as a threatened species under the [Species Act](Endangered)(Endangered Species Act), citing the melting of Arctic sea ice as the primary threat to the polar bear. It banned all importing of polar bear trophies. Importing products made from polar bears had been prohibited from 1972 to 1994 under the Marine Mammal Protection Act, and restricted between 1994 and 2008. Under those restrictions, permits from the [States Fish and Wildlife Service](United)(United States Fish and Wildlife Service) were required to import sport-hunted polar bear trophies taken in hunting expeditions in Canada. The permit process required that the bear be taken from an area with quotas based on sound management principles. Since 1994, hundreds of sport-hunted polar bear trophies have been imported into the U.S.["Support the Polar Bear Protection Act"](https://web.archive.org/web/20081126220037/https://community.hsus.org/campaign/FED_2007_polar_bear_trophy2). The Humane Society of the United States In 2015, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service published a draft conservation management plan for polar bears to improve their status under the Endangered Species Act and the Marine Mammal Protection Act. Draft.

[[bear in Denver Zoo.jpg|thumb|Polar bear in Denver Zoo.](File:Polar)]
The five nations that are signatories of the Agreement on the Conservation of Polar Bears are Canada, Greenland, Norway, Russia, and the United States.

# Miyamoto Musashi

*Revision ID: 1159711180 | Timestamp: 2023-06-12T02:18:13Z*

---

| birth_place     = [Province](Harima)(Harima Province) or [Province](Mimasaka)(Mimasaka Province), Japan

| death_date      =

| death_place     = [Province](Higo)(Higo Province), Japan

| martial_art     = *[Niten Ichi-ryū](Hyōhō)(Hyōhō Niten Ichi-ryū) [Kenjutsu](Kenjutsu)* (二天一流), Enmei-ryu (圓明流), (二天流)

| students        = [Yoemon](Takemura)(Takemura Yoemon); [Magonojō](Terao)(Terao Magonojō); [Motomenosuke](Terao)(Terao Motomenosuke); [Sōzaemon](Furuhashi)(Furuhashi Sōzaemon)

| children        = [Mikinosuke](Miyamoto Mikinosuke) (adopted)[Kurōtarō](Miyamoto Kurōtarō) (adopted)[Iori](Miyamoto Iori) (adopted)[Yoemon](Hirao Yoemon) (adopted)Daughter of unknown name

| module          =

}}

, also known as **Shinmen Takezō**, **Miyamoto Bennosuke** or, by his [name](Buddhist)(Dharma name), **Niten Dōraku**,Toyota Masataka. "Niten Ki (A Chronicle of Two Heavens)", in *Gorin no Sho*, ed. Kamiko Tadashi (Tokyo: Tokuma-shoten, 1963), 239. was a Japanese [swordsman](swordsman), philosopher, strategist, writer and [rōnin](rōnin), who became renowned through stories of his unique double-bladed swordsmanship and undefeated record in his 61 duels (next is 33 by [Ittōsai](Itō)(Itō Ittōsai)). Musashi, as he was often simply known, is considered a [*Kensei*](Kensei (honorary title)), a sword-saint of Japan.Miyamoto Musashi, trans.S. F. Kaufman (1994), *Book Of Five Rings*, Tuttle Publishing. He was the founder of the [Ichi-ryū](Niten)(Niten Ichi-ryū), or Nito Ichi-ryū, style of swordsmanship, and in his final years authored  and *[Dokkōdō](Dokkōdō)* (獨行道, *The Path of Aloneness*).

Both documents were given to [Magonojō](Terao)(Terao Magonojō), the most important of Musashi's students, seven days before Musashi's death. *The Book of Five Rings* deals primarily with the character of his [Ichi-ryū](Niten)(Niten Ichi-ryū) school in a concrete sense, i.e., his own practical martial art and its generic significance; *The Path of Aloneness*, on the other hand, deals with the ideas that lie behind it, as well as his life's philosophy in a few short aphoristic sentences.

The [Musashi Budokan](Miyamoto)(Miyamoto Musashi Budokan) training center, located in [Ōhara-chō](Ōhara, Okayama) ([Mimasaka](Mimasaka, Okayama)), [prefecture](Okayama)(Okayama Prefecture), [Japan](Japan) was erected to honor his name and legend.

[[File:Musashi budokan02s2640.jpg|thumb|The [Musashi Budokan](Miyamoto)(Miyamoto Musashi Budokan) in [Ōhara-chō](Ōhara, Okayama) ([Mimasaka](Mimasaka, Okayama)), [prefecture](Okayama)(Okayama Prefecture), [Japan](Japan)]]
## Biography
Miyamoto Musashi's cause of death is believed to be natural causes. He died in Higo Province, Japan, but specific details about the exact cause are not clearly documented.

## Plot

Eva Khatchadourian, once a successful [writer](travel)(travel writer), lives alone in a rundown house and works in a travel agency near a prison, where she visits her son Kevin. She reflects upon her memories of raising him as she tries to cope with the hostility of her neighbors.

A reluctant mother, Eva views Kevin as detached and difficult from childhood. He appears to loathe and deliberately antagonize Eva, who struggles to bond with him. As a baby, he cries incessantly, but only around her; as a child, he resists [training](toilet)(toilet training), rebuffs Eva's attempts at affection, and shows no interest in anything. He behaves like a happy, loving son in front of his father Franklin, who dismisses Eva's concerns and makes excuses for Kevin's behavior. One day, Eva's frustration with Kevin drives her to throw him against the wall, breaking his arm. Kevin tells Franklin he fell and uses the incident to manipulate Eva, threatening to tell Franklin the truth if she does not do things he wants.

When Kevin is confined to bed with a fever, he shows affection towards Eva for the first time as she reads [Hood](Robin)(Robin Hood), though his spiteful personality returns as soon as he recovers. Franklin gives Kevin a [and arrow](bow)(bow and arrow) and teaches him [archery](archery).

Sometime later, Eva gives birth to her and Franklin's second child Celia, a lively and cheerful girl whom Kevin is instantly disdainful towards. A few years later, Celia's pet guinea pig mysteriously goes missing. Eva finds its remains in the [disposal](garbage)(garbage disposal) the next day, which she unclogs with [cleaner](drain)(drain cleaner). Celia is blinded in one eye after being exposed to the cleaner while Kevin was tasked with watching her, requiring her to wear a glass eye in its place. Eva suspects Kevin injured his sister on purpose, but Franklin defends him. Tired of Eva's distrust of their son, Franklin discusses divorce with her, and Kevin overhears their conversation.

Three days before his 16th birthday, Kevin uses bicycle locks to trap several students in the school gymnasium and murders them with his bow and arrows. After witnessing Kevin’s arrest and the bodies of his victims being carried away, Eva returns home to discover that Kevin has murdered Franklin and Celia as well.

On the second anniversary of the massacre, Eva visits Kevin in prison; his demeanor has changed to demure and frightened in his anticipation of being transferred to an adult prison. Eva finally asks him why he committed the murders. Kevin responds that he used to think he knew but is no longer sure. Eva gives Kevin a warm embrace before leaving.

The film you are referring to is "We Need to Talk About Kevin," a 2011 drama film. However, it's important to note that this film stars Tilda Swinton as Eva and Ezra Miller as Kevin. It tells the story of a woman coping with the aftermath of her son Kevin's violence.

## Etymology

[[van Strij - Het Jacht van de kamer Rotterdam.jpg|thumb|An 18th-century Dutch *jacht*](File:Jacob)]

The term, *yacht*, originates from the [Dutch](Dutch language) word *jacht* (pl. *jachten*, which means "hunt"), and originally referred to light, fast sailing vessels that the [Republic](Dutch)(Dutch Republic) navy used to pursue [pirate](pirate)s and other transgressors around and into the shallow waters of the [Countries](Low)(Low Countries).

The word "yacht" originates from the Dutch word "jacht," which means "hunt." Originally, it referred to light, fast sailing vessels used by the Dutch navy to pursue pirates and other transgressors in the shallow waters of the Low Countries.

**Sir William Wallace** (, ; [French](Norman)(Anglo-Norman language): ; 23 August 1305) was a Scottish [knight](knight) who became one of the main leaders during the [War of Scottish Independence](First)(First War of Scottish Independence).

Along with [Moray](Andrew)(Andrew Moray), Wallace defeated an English army at the [of Stirling Bridge](Battle)(Battle of Stirling Bridge) in September 1297. He was appointed [of Scotland](Guardian)(Guardian of Scotland) and served until his defeat at the [of Falkirk](Battle)(Battle of Falkirk) in July 1298. In August 1305, Wallace was captured in [Robroyston](Robroyston), near [Glasgow](Glasgow), and handed over to King [I of England](Edward)(Edward I of England), who had him [drawn and quartered](hanged,)(hanged, drawn and quartered) for [treason](high)(high treason) and crimes against English civilians.

Since his death, Wallace has obtained a legendary status far beyond his homeland. He is the [protagonist](protagonist) of [Harry](Blind)(Blind Harry)'s 15th-century epic poem *[Wallace](The)(The Wallace (poem))* and the subject of literary works by [Porter](Jane)(Jane Porter) and Sir [Scott](Walter)(Walter Scott), and of the [Award](Academy)(Academy Award)-winning film *[Braveheart](Braveheart)*.
William Wallace served as the Guardian of Scotland from 1297 to 1298.
